David Saff wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>  > They are similar. They also point to an observation I've made about
>  > abstract classes, explaining why I prefer not to use them.
>  >
>  > Every abstract class consists of two parts: the abstract part and the
>  > concrete part. The concrete part consists of all the fields and methods
>  > with implementations (bodies). The abstract part consists of all the
>  > declarations of abstract methods.
> 
> I've had the same suspicion for a while, but have recently refined it. 
> I now avoid abstract classes _with state_.  Stateless abstract classes
> work well as interfaces with default implementations, and I think of
> them more that way.  For examples, see Runner and RunListener in JUnit
> 4.  (Actually, RunListener is not abstract, but I'm hard-pressed to
> think why it would be useful to instantiate it.

A stateless abstract class is usually a Strategy, so I'd rather use it 
than extend it. One exception is the empty Strategy, otherwise known as 
an Adapter. I usually find those useful for very flexible Strategies 
where I only need to implement a small percentage of the methods.

> I otherwise agree with your analysis.

That's always comforting. (No, that's not sarcasm for those of you 
wondering.)
